abstract.text: Information about a real-world surface found by examining a point on the screen.

inlineContent.text: as your renderer, you can search for real-world surfaces at a screen point using the
If you use a custom renderer, you can find real-world positions using screen points with:

abstract.text: Integrate hardware sensing features to produce augmented reality apps and games.
A video image captured as part of a session with position-tracking information.
Get a ray-cast query for a screen point.
A mathematical ray you use to find 3D positions on real-world surfaces.
The types of surface you allow a raycast to intersect with.
A specification that indicates a target’s alignment with respect to gravity
Information about a real-world surface found by examining a point on the screen.
The anchor for the plane that the ray intersected.
The type of surface that the ray intersects.
The alignment of the plane that the ray intersected.
The position, rotation, and scale, of the ray’s intersection with the target.
A view that blends virtual 3D content from SceneKit into your augmented reality experience.
Creates a raycast query that originates from a point on the view, aligned with the center of the camera’s field of view.
The object that manages the major tasks associated with every AR experience, such as motion tracking, camera passthrough, and image analysis.
Checks once for intersections between a ray and real-world surfaces.
Repeats a ray-cast query over time to notify you of updated surfaces in the physical environment.
A raycast query that ARKit repeats in succession to give you refined results over time.
Place virtual content at tracked, real-world locations, and enable the user to interact with virtual content by using gestures.
A view that enables you to display an AR experience with RealityKit.
Performs a ray cast, where a ray is cast into the scene from the center of the camera through a point in the view, and the results are immediately returned.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
